At that time the World-Honored One again told the powerful youth VimalakÄ«rti, Son of a great clan!
If bodhisattvas hear of such practices, they should diligently uphold and practice them.

How so? They should seek to hear and listen to the elders, always practice respectfulness, abandon arrogance, speak gently, and be kind and gentle by nature. They should contemplate the Dharma as if it were medicine, and toward their teachers and preceptors, think of them as the World-Honored One. They should examine their own bodies and think of selecting the Dharma as medicine, and give rise to the thought of being a great physician, and toward all beings, think of them as having illnesses.

If they strive to seek the Dharma, they should not cherish their bodies, crave for life, rely on longevity, or be attached to appearance and clothing. They should always delight in the scriptures and take the Dharma as their basis.

They should give away all that they have without stinginess, be dedicated to the principles of the Dharma, and disregard material gain. They should protect the Dharma treasure and be apart from the precious things of the world.

For the sake of the Dharma, they eliminate all worldly wealth and goods, and with the treasure of the Dharma, they remove the cherished treasures of ordinary people. Wishing to eliminate the defilements, afflictions, desires, and all faults of sentient beings, they should always aspire to and seek the scriptures of the true Dharma.

Wishing to deliver all types of sentient beings to the state of nirvana, they should then uphold and guide them with the true Dharma. Those who are able to guide and protect the scriptures of the true Dharma will be able to universally obtain and cultivate all the roots of virtue.

For this reason, if there are people who wish to seek the Buddha's path, who wish to attain supreme perfect enlightenment, and who wish to establish the Dharma pillar, they should study extensive learning.
It is like, son of noble family!
Mount Sumeru, the king of mountains, is a great pillar for the gods. If it were a pillar in the heavens, it would be lofty and cover much, adorning the Heaven of the Thirty-three. The Buddha said:
Thus, a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who extensively studies and hears becomes a pillar of wisdom, and wherever he dwells, whether in the heavens or the world, his radiance is majestic.
If, son of a great clan!

If there are bodhisattvas who aspire to the Buddha's path and think 'I shall attain Buddhahood,' they should understand skillful means, extensively study and hear, always cultivate diligence, and for all sentient beings who are in wrong knowledge, they should light the lamp of wisdom.
If a bodhisattva enters extensive learning and diligently seeks wisdom, he will be replete with the wisdom of sentient beings and will have accomplished what he should do.
At that time, the devas will then raise their voices to praise and rejoice with delight, and a wholesome mind will arise, thinking:

'Now, this true man, with such an appearance and form, through the power of extensive learning, attains the ten powers, realizes supreme perfect enlightenment, and his faculties are clear and penetrating. Such beneficial matters are the practices of a bodhisattva.'

Grasping the sword of wisdom to cut off all the desires of dust and toil, if a bodhisattva has such an appearance, he is able to bear the sutra Dharma spoken by the bright wisdom, and can then remove the dust and toil, danger and difficulty of sentient beings.

If a bodhisattva has such an appearance, he is then able to speak the Dharma to eliminate love and desire. Such a bodhisattva is then able to return to the dwelling places of the ancient World-Honored Ones. Such an appearance is then able to subdue Mara and his officials, and is then able to turn the Dharma wheel with the twelve aspects.
Thus, son of noble family!

If a bodhisattva mahasattva diligently studies and establishes himself in sagely understanding, then at that time all the Maras in the trichiliocosm will all become worried, depressed, and difficult to bear:
Now this bodhisattva does not follow my teachings and goes against my original intention. They are all abandoned and cannot be controlled.
Why is it so?
Son of noble family!

From hearing, one attains wisdom. Wisdom is the most venerable in the midst of defilements and desires. Those without defilements and desires cannot be taken advantage of by the demon of desire. For this reason, one should contemplate in this way.

If a bodhisattva opens up and enters into extensive learning, discriminates the scriptures, and delights in the Dharma, from then on, whatever teachings he imparts, he subdues the various demons, the demon of desire and defilements, the demon of the five aggregates, the demon of arising and ceasing, and the demon of the heavens and their retinue. These are the four demons that are naturally subdued.
Moreover, son of noble family!

Just as the bodhisattvas of the past entered into extensive learning, discriminated the principles of the Dharma, and delighted in the scriptures. Now, I shall roughly outline and briefly explain their essentials.
In the distant past, countless eons ago, immeasurable and incalculable, vast and boundless, inconceivable,

at that time, in that eon, there was a sage named Uttara. Dwelling in the forest, he attained the five supernatural powers. Always practicing the mind of equanimity, kindness, compassion, joy, and protection, he roamed in the secluded wilds, thinking to himself:
'I practice loving-kindness, my body is soft and tender, always joyful and at ease;

I cannot use loving-kindness to eliminate the self-indulgent desires of sentient beings, nor can I remove anger and ignorance, the desires of the far-off dusty paths of afflictions, and with this loving-kindness I cannot attain the right view of the sages and worthies.
I cannot attain blessings, how can I attain the equal observation of sages and worthies?'
He further thought to himself:
'One can always rely on two things to attain the right view of sages and worthies.
What are the two?
Listening to the teachings of others and contemplating in a still mind.
' He then rejoiced and gave rise to great diligence, and also entered the Dharma.
'Where can I hear this teaching?'
He then sought the scriptures because of the Dharma, entering the counties, prefectures, and villages, seeking the scriptures but never hearing them.
At that time, a heavenly being of Mara went to him and said:
'Son of a great clan!

I have a Buddha's name that will protect you. If you, son of a good family, were to torment your body, expose yourself to the sun, and hear the sound of protection from your own body, then you could write these verses.
Then I will allow you to hear these four lines of the verse.'
At that time, son of a good family!
The ascetic Utpala thought to himself:

'Since beginningless kalpas, I have abandoned this body, enjoying imprisonment, beatings, whips, and lashes, or with a sharp knife cutting the body into pieces, the body scattered, flesh and skin severed, due to desire I have been bound, and experienced these countless calamities;
I do not care for this body, nor for the pain and itching, and have never used my body to benefit others.
If I can already guide and benefit the multitude, I will use this insubstantial body to seek the scriptures;
I will obtain good benefits and be joyful, and will follow the heavenly beings to hear the scriptures.'

I have never had such a thought, he thought, I will give rise to the World-Honored One's mind and harbor respectful submission. Then, he took a sharp knife and cut his own body, roasting it in the sun from ear to ear.
And he said to the god:

May the god expound the Buddha's name and protect the recitation. I will give up my body out of respect for the Dharma and not begrudge my life. By this cause and condition, I will gather and hear what I have not heard.
At that time, son of a great clan!

Seeing the supreme sage's respectful submission and joy in the Dharma like this, his complexion was haggard and emaciated, and his merits were difficult to behold, so he disappeared and was no longer visible.
Then the supreme sage thought to himself:
Will he not test me and hear this verse?
Will he respectfully follow the Dharma and give up his body without begrudging his life in order to hear it?

I have respectfully compiled the scriptures and planted roots of virtue without losing their merit or being deceived. If my body is truly sincere, straightforward, and without flattery, and if I have compassion for sentient beings and do not covet my body or life, but give up my body and life, then by this sincerity, those who hear this Dharma will, in this very world and in the buddha-lands of other directions, be able to cultivate the Dharma. May these people manifest their faces and forms, so that I may see them and hear the sutra Dharma.
As soon as he made this vow, he spoke again.

At that time, below, beyond thirty-two buddha-lands, there was a world called Universal Equality and Freedom from Defilement, where the Buddha was called the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the Present Teacher of the Dharma, the Worthy One.
At that time, the Buddha immediately saw the thoughts in the sage's mind and also wanted to teach and transform the people of Jambudvipa.

Just as a strong man can bend or stretch his arm at will, in the same way, in the time it takes to bend or stretch one's arm, that Buddha suddenly disappeared from his own land and appeared before the sage, together with five hundred bodhisattvas.

The Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the King of Unstained Renown, due to the conditions of the immortal practitioners, expounded for the celestial sons and bodhisattvas the samadhi of the equal collection of various merits.

The Buddha told Utmost Victory:

The Buddha told Utmost Excellence:

What are the eight?
The seal phrase of emptiness, without relying on anything, manifests the present Dharma;
The seal phrase of signlessness, without establishing anything, manifests the scriptures;
The seal phrase of wishlessness, without relying on, leaning on, attaching to, or seeking anything, manifests the present Dharma;
The seal phrase of the fundamental realm, the seal phrase of fundamental emptiness, equally controlling them, manifests the scriptures;
The seal phrase of the Dharma realm, equally controlling all dharmas, manifests their basis;
The seal phrase of non-basis, manifesting entry into all dharmas;
Just like the seal phrase, removing and eliminating the basis of present and future manifested dharmas;
The seal of cessation is the ultimate cessation, forever eliminating the fundamental basis of all phenomena.
This is the supreme!
The eight seals all discern and accomplish the equality of all phenomena.
Therefore, Supreme!
The words of mastery and the words of questions, the words of diligence and the various seal words, should always be peacefully and properly practiced and diligently studied.

Chapter on the Three Kinds of Practice.
Among the three kinds of things, extensive learning is the most revered, the most excellent, the longest, and has no equal.
It is like Mount Sumeru;
Upholding precepts and giving alms are like a mustard seed next to Mount Sumeru. One should contemplate that extensive learning is like Mount Sumeru.
It is like a flying bird soaring in the sky, the shadow of its feet covers only a little bit.
Upholding precepts and giving alms are like this.
It is like the boundless vastness of space. The virtue of extensive learning is like this!
Why is it so?
Son of a great clan!
Giving has two benefits: leaving poverty and gaining great wealth.
Precepts have two benefits: transcending evil destinies and being reborn in the heavens.
Learning has two benefits: attaining holy wisdom and eliminating wrong views.
Those who give do not leave the aggregates that are received by the various defilements.
Those who uphold precepts, the aggregates that are received are also together with the defilements.
Those of extensive learning are free from defilements and do not grasp at the aggregates.
For this reason, VimalatejÄ!
This is called the bodhisattva's appropriate extensive learning.

When the Buddha spoke of giving, morality, and extensive learning, 32,000 beings planted roots of virtue and all generated the intention for unsurpassed, true, and equal enlightenment. Universally cultivating great kindness and adding to all sentient beings;

Giving all one has without stinginess;

Tranquilly eliminating afflictions;

Certifying the divisions in the three liberation gates;
